On Tue, 12 Oct 2004 07:49:35 -0700, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> 
> As a side note, what I hear in all this discussion is an effort to
> sort of re-invent backpropagation...  The point being that if we take
> a moment to recognize that that is what we are doing, we might be able
> to draw from what has already been done in that field.
> 
> -- John

Interesting point. I wonder would there be a benefit to be had (in
some problem domains at least) from applying a modicum of backprop to
a NEAT network? Weights would then be "nudged" towards more
"appropriate" levels (to direct the error-reduction endeavour) with
mutation still available to escape from local minima.

For some classification and function approximation domains I can see
this being useful. Well, any domain where the outputs for a training
set are known. You know, the type of problem  for which backprop has
historically been useful. A big problem with vanilla backprop has
always been the fixed topology - NEAT offers a way out of that trap,
but the propagate-forward/backpropagate-errors idea could offer a
shortcut to finding better weights for a given topology.

--Mike
